title: 105_s2347
content: The Act may be cited as the Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act and aims to expand prevention efforts for methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act aims to prevent methamphetamine abuse by providing grants for school-based and community-based prevention programs. The Director of the Center for Substance Abuse Prevention can make grants to public and non-profit entities for effective and evidence-based prevention programs. The funds provided under the Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act are to be used for planning, establishing, or administering prevention programs focused on districts with high rates of methamphetamine abuse. These programs can be school-based or community-based, targeting populations at risk for methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act aims to target populations at risk for methamphetamine abuse by providing funds for prevention activities, training law enforcement officials, monitoring prevention efforts, and implementing targeted pilot programs. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act provides funds for prevention activities, training law enforcement officials, monitoring prevention efforts, and implementing targeted pilot programs in rural and urban areas experiencing high rates of methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Additionally, funds are allocated for analyses and evaluations of effective prevention programs. The Director will conduct periodic analyses and evaluations of prevention programs for methamphetamine abuse, submit annual reports to specific committees, and authorize appropriations of $20,000,000 for fiscal year 1999. SEC. 3. EXPANDING CRIMINAL PENALTIES AND LAW ENFORCEMENT FUNDING. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend sentencing guidelines for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine in accordance with federal laws. The base offense level will be increased for these offenses. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase the base offense level for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine by at least 3 levels above the current level or to level 27 if lower. Additionally, if the offense poses a substantial risk to another person's health and safety, the offense level will be increased. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase the base offense level for offenses posing a risk to another person's health and safety by at least 6 levels above the current level or to level 30 if lower. The Commission will promptly implement guidelines or amendments in accordance with the new legislation. The United States Sentencing Commission will promptly implement guidelines or amendments in accordance with the new legislation. Increased resources are authorized to combat methamphetamine trafficking in designated areas. SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF METHAMPHETAMINE ABUSE. Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for expanding treatment programs for methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Funds can be used for evidence-based programs to help individuals quit methamphetamine use. The subsection allows grants for evidence-based programs to help individuals quit methamphetamine use, training health professionals in recognizing and treating methamphetamine abuse, planning and administering treatment activities, and monitoring and evaluating treatment outcomes. The Director shall prioritize grants for rural and urban areas with high rates of methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Activities include planning, administration, monitoring, evaluation, reporting, pilot programs, and coordination with mental health services. The Director prioritizes grants for rural and urban areas with high rates of methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Up to $1,000,000 annually is allocated for analyses, evaluations, and development of effective treatments, with a focus on disseminating information and implementing treatment services. Annual reports are submitted to specific Senate committees. The Director submits an annual report to specific Senate committees with the results of analyses and evaluations conducted. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, with additional funding as needed for each following year. SEC. 5. EXPANDING METHAMPHETAMINE RESEARCH. Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, focusing on its effects on the human body, addictive nature, connection to mental illness, and prevention methods. The amended Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act allows grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction. This research focuses on the effects of methamphetamine abuse on the human body, its addictive nature, connection to mental illness, prevention methods, risk factors, effects on pregnant women and fetuses, and reasons for abuse. The Director is required to disseminate research results to relevant entities promptly. The amended Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act authorizes appropriations of $16,000,000 for fiscal year 1999 and additional funds for subsequent years to disseminate research results on methamphetamine abuse and addiction to relevant entities.
